titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas Thistlewood Papers
titlestmt.author: by Diane Ducharme

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:50

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers consist of diaries, weather journals, commonplace books, reading notes and other material documenting the life, work, and intellectual interests of the Jamaican planter and slaveowner Thomas Thistlewood. Thistlewood's 37 diaries, in Series I, contain daily entries dating between 1750 and 1786. Topics include Thistlewood's work as an overseer, and later owner, of slaves, including his methods of assigning work, alloting provisions, and discipline; his personal and sexual relationships with several, including his lengthy relationship with Phibbah; and slave rebellions and rumors of rebellions, including Tacky's Revolt (1760). Other topics include personal and professional relationships with other white Jamaicans, including his first employer, John Cope, and his family; purchases and expenses; meals and other entertainments; and recreational activities. The diary for 1763 is bound with A manuscript treatise on planting, by Mr. John Palley Edwards. There is one diary by Thistlewood's nephew, John Thistlewood (d. 1768).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Sotheby's London on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Fund, 2011.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: From the collection of William John Monson, Baron Monson. Deposited at Lincolnshire Archives in 1951.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Thomas Thistlewood Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Thomas Thistlewood Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including housing and minimal organization, in 2011.

The 92 volumes of the Thistlewood Papers were arranged and numbered in the nineteenth century while in the possession of William John Monson, Baron Monson, and this order has been preserved in this finding aid.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is partially drawn from information supplied with the collection by Sotheby's London. This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Thomas Thistlewood (1721-1786)
bioghist.p: Thomas Thistlewood (1721-1786), was born in Lincolnshire, England. The second son of a farmer, he was educated in Ackworth, Yorkshire, where he received training in mathematics and in "practical science." After a two- year voyage on one of the East India Company's ships as its supercargo, Thistlewood returned to England and decided to seek employment in Jamaica, emigrating in 1750.

He began his Caribbean life as an overseer of sugar plantations, principally of John Cope's Egypt plantation in Westmoreland parish, where he supervised numerous slaves in sugar production. During these years, Thistlewood gradually acquired slaves of his own, whom he rented out to other planters. In 1767 he completed the purchase of his own plantation, Breadnut Island, a "pen" where his thirty or so slaves raised provisions and livestock.

Thistlewood also pursued a variety of scientific and intellectual interests. He acquired several hundred books, often on scientific and technical subjects; collected and described medicinal plants and other botanical specimens; and kept a detailed weather record for thirty-four years. The gardens at Breadnut Island were considered among the finest in western Jamaica before they were ruined in the hurricane of October 1780.

Thistlewood never married, but had one son, Mulatto John (d. 1780), by his slave Phibbah, who was originally a slave of his employer. Thistlewood eventually purchased her from Cope and lived with her at Breadnut Island; he called her his "wife" in the will that freed her. He never returned to England, and died at Breadnut Island, Jamaica in November 1786.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of diaries, weather journals, commonplace books, reading notes and other material documenting the life, work, and intellectual interests of the Jamaican planter and slaveowner Thomas Thistlewood. Daily entries in the diaries, which Thistlewood kept from 1748 until a few weeks before his death in 1786, are a rich source of information on plantation life and work, including management of sugar plantations and livestock plantations; economic and social relations among landowners, overseers and slaves; and Thistlewood's own professional, intellectual and sexual activities. Thirty-four years of weather journals chronicle the Jamaican climate, including the great hurricane of October 1780, while twenty volumes of reading notes, memoranda, inventories, lists of books, and other papers reveal Thistlewood's intellectual and scientific interests, such as botany and the collection of medicinal plants; chemistry; mathematics; and navigation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Diaries, 1748-1786; II. Weather Reports, 1752-1786; III.Reading Notes and Other Papers, 1748-1792.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two subseries: Diaries of Thomas Thistlewood and Diary of John Thistlewood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Diaries , consists of 37 diaries containing daily entries dating between 1750 and 1786. Topics include Thistlewood's work as an overseer, and later owner, of slaves, including his methods of assigning work, alloting provisions, and discipline; his personal and sexual relationships with several slaves, including his lengthy relationship with Phibbah, his slave "wife"; and slave rebellions and rumors of rebellions, particularly Tacky's Revolt (1760). Other topics include personal and professional relationships with white Jamaicans, including his first employer, John Cope, and his family; purchases and expenses; meals and other entertainments; and recreational activities. The diary for 1763 is bound with A manuscript treatise on planting, by Mr. John Palley Edwards . There is one diary by Thistlewood's nephew, John Thistlewood (d. 1768).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains entries for January only. 37 pages of loose entries laid in at the end of the volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound with: A Manuscript Treatise on Planting, by Mr. John Palley Edwards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also includes list of books and other items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Weather Journals , consists of 34 annual journals containing daily weather summaries, including precipitation measurements. Diaries from 1764 through 1767 also contain separate lists of daily Fahrenheit temperatures and rainfall amounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Reading Notes and Other Papers , consists of twenty volumes, most in Thistlewood's hand, containing extensive reading notes; scientific notes; botanical and medical observations; inventories of slaves, books, moveable property, and game; and some accounts and miscellaneous memoranda. Volumes include Mr. Richard Beckford's Instructions for overseers of sugar plantations; a scribal volume of navigational problems; and a volume containing items relating to Jamaica, including poems and council meeting minutes.

did.unittitle: 73. Reading notes, commonplace entries and memoranda

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on scientific subjects, including electricity; natural history; travel and exploration; alphabets and languages; mathematics, including magic squares; and poetry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include a variety of reading notes; medical receipts; lists of plants with some sketches; mathematical notes; and financial notes including copies of bonds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include a variety of reading notes and lists of plants, some with sketches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include reading notes; notes on natural history, practical science, and indigo production; and observations and statistic concerning the West Indies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scientific notes, including extensive Extracts, from a Course of Lectures on Chymisty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include extensive notes from A Course of Experimentall Philosophy by J. T. Desaguliers , including some machinery sketches; notes concerning Jamaica and tables recording slave labor, 1754-1756

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Extracts from and comments on A New and Complete Dictionary of Arts and Sciences, By a Society of Gentlemen (1754)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Extracts from and comments on The Philosophical Grammar by Benjamin Martin; A New Geographical and Historical Grammar , by Salmon; and other works; also includes mechanical sketches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Almost entirely lists of books belonging to Thistlewood and to others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lists of books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes notes on Thistlewood family history and antiquarian and topographical notes on Lincolnshire

did.unittitle: 85. Inventories of property taken by Thistlewood to Jamaica

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes lists of books

did.unittitle: 86. Westmoreland April 10th 1754. Mr. Richard Beckford's Instructions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In six sections, headed "1. The Care and Management of White Servants & Slaves; 2. of Mules & Neat Cattle; 3. Of Buildings; 4. The Culture of the Soil; 5. The Making of Sugar; 6. The Distillery."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include minutes of meetings of the council of war; memoranda; and satirical poems

did.unittitle: 88. Jamaica. List of Negroes belonging to Mr. Thomas Thistlewood, formerly of Tupholme Lincolnshire, with a Tabular account of their weekly labour, between 1758 & 1766

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include detailed weather reports for Egypt Plantation for 1767; a memorandum on the climate of Jamaica; an explanation of Thistlewood's methodology in taking these weather measurements; and a poem copied from the St. Jago Intelligencer

did.unittitle: 90. An Account of the Gaim which I shot in the Island of Jamaica Beginning in the Year 1764

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thistlewood's game book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript textbook, in a single scribal hand, containing various problem sets relating to charting courses, methods of sailing, measurement and gauging, and geometry
Laid in: autograph letter signed from John Carter to J. S. Padley, Horncastle, 1853 November 22. Concerns the ownership of the Thistlewood papers.
Enclosure: autograph letter signed from J. F. Wray to an unidentified recipient, 1852 February 9

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes recording information on farming in Lincolnshire, including weather reports; probably by a Thistlewood family member
